title: How to Make a Bolster Pillow

steps.title: Fold the fabric in half, right-side facing in.
steps.content: Fold the fabric in half, right-side facing in. Set the paint can on top of the fabric, near the bottom edge. Trace around the paint can with the fabric marker. Cut 2 pieces of fabric around the traced line. This will give you 2 circles for the ends of the decorative pillow.

steps.title: Stitch a row of long stitches around each circle.
steps.content: Stitch a row of long stitches around each circle. It should be .5 inches (1.27 cm) away from the edge. This is the seam that will connect the tube to the ends.

steps.title: Clip this edge of each circle of the bolster pillow, .5 inches (1.27 cm) apart, all the way around.
steps.content: Clip this edge of each circle of the bolster pillow, .5 inches (1.27 cm) apart, all the way around. Clip up to the stitched line, but not through it. The clipped edges will make it easier for you to sew the pillow together in the end.

steps.title: Find the circumference of the 2 circles by measuring the diameter.
steps.content: Find the circumference of the 2 circles by measuring the diameter. You can do this by multiplying the diameter of the circle by 3.14 for the circumference. You need this measurement to find out how much fabric to cut for the middle of the bolster pillow. For example, if the diameter of the circles is 5 inches (12.7 cm), the circumference is 15.7 inches (39.9 cm), or 5 x 3.14.

steps.title: Cut a rectangle of fabric.
steps.content: Cut a rectangle of fabric. Use the circumference plus 1 inch (2.54 cm) (for the seam allowance) and 24 inches (60 cm) long.

steps.title: Fold the rectangle in half lengthwise, right-side facing in.
steps.content: Fold the rectangle in half lengthwise, right-side facing in. Pin the 24-inch (60 cm) edge together. Sew the pillow along this 24-inch (60 cm) edge, .5" (1.27 cm) from each edge, forming a tube.

steps.title: Pin the edges of one circle to one edge of the rectangle piece of fabric.
steps.content: Pin the edges of one circle to one edge of the rectangle piece of fabric. The inside should be facing out as you're pinning.

steps.title: Pull on the long row of stitches on the circle to gather it.
steps.content: Pull on the long row of stitches on the circle to gather it. This is so that it fits inside the rounded edge of the rectangle. If you don't, you'll have excess fabric on the edges of your pillow.

steps.title: Start sewing the circle to the edge of the rectangle.
steps.content: Start sewing the circle to the edge of the rectangle. Use the row of long stitches on the fabric as a guide as you sew the pillow, so that they will be concealed when the decorative pillow is finished. Repeat with the second circle if you are using the polyester batting. Don't sew the second side all up! Leave a 3-inch (7.62 cm) gap so you can add the batting to the bolster pillow.

steps.title: Fold the towel so that it measures 24 inches (60 cm) long.
steps.content: Fold the towel so that it measures 24 inches (60 cm) long. That is, if you're using it. Pre-made bolster pillow shapes are available and can be easily substituted. Just make sure they're the right size and shape beforehand. Roll the towel so that it is the same diameter as the decorative pillow.

steps.title: Turn the fabric of the pillow right-side out.
steps.content: Turn the fabric of the pillow right-side out. Then slide the rolled towel inside. Make sure the towel maintains its shape or you'll end up with a bumpy, uncomfortable pillow.

steps.title: Hand-sew the second circle to the pillow, making sure to conceal the raw edges.
steps.content: Hand-sew the second circle to the pillow, making sure to conceal the raw edges. Turn the fabric of the pillow right-side out if you're using the batting. Stuff the bolster pillow with the batting and hand-sew the pillow closed!
